'''William Morgan''', [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (26 May 1750 – 4 May 1833) was a [[Wales|Welsh]] [[physician]], [[physicist]] and [[statistician]], who is considered the father of modern [[actuarial science]].

==Life==
He was born in [[Bridgend]], [[Glamorganshire]], son to physician William Morgan and  Sarah, née Price. His brother was [[George Cadogan Morgan]]. At eighteen he came to London for medical training at [[Guy's Hospital]], working also as an [[apothecary]] to pay his way. He did not complete his training, but after one year returned to Bridgend to join his father's practice. He was not popular with his father's patients: they thought him inexperienced and they resented receiving treatment from someone with a deformity—Morgan suffered from a club foot. 
After his father's death he left medicine and, on the recommendation of his mother's brother, [[Richard Price]],  in 1774 was appointed Assistant [[Actuary]] of [[The Equitable Life Assurance Society]].
{{sfn|Thomas|1894}} 
In February 1775, after the death of John Pocock, he was elected Actuary. By the time he retired on 2 December 1830, 56 years later at the age of 80, he laid the foundations of [[actuary|the actuarial profession]] —in fact the term "actuarial" became attached to the profession because of his title.

He won the [[Copley Medal]] in 1789, for his two papers on the values of Reversions and Survivorships,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://royalsociety.org/General_WF.aspx?pageid=7035&terms=william+morgan&fragment=&SearchType=&terms=william%20morgan|title=Copley Medal  — 1799 - 1731|publisher=[[The Royal Society]]|accessdate=12 July 2010|location=London}}</ref> printed in the last two volumes of the [[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]], in the field of [[actuarial science]]:
* ''On the Probabilities of Survivorships Between Two Persons of Any Given Ages, and the Method of Determining the Values of Reversions Depending on those Survivorships'', 1788–1794
* ''On  the Method of Determining, from the Real Probabilities of Life, the Value of a Contingent Reversion in Which Three Lives are Involved in the Survivorship''. [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k558848/f50.item Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London, Vol. 79 (1789)] pp. 40–54

He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society|Fellow]] of the Society, in May of the following year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://royalsociety.org/Lists-of-Royal-Society-Fellows-1660-2007/|title=Lists of Royal Society Fellows 1660-2007|publisher=The Royal Society|accessdate=16 July 2010|location=London}}</ref>

Advised by [[Joseph Priestley]], a family friend, he developed an interest in scientific experimentation and is credited with being the first to record the "invisible light" produced when a current is passed through a partly [[vacuum|evacuated]] glass tube: "the first x-ray tube".<ref>{{Citation

Later in life, through his uncle, [[Richard Price]],  he became friends with noted [[Radicalism (historical)|radicals]], including [[Tom Paine]] and [[Francis Burdett]]. 
He escaped with only a warning when in 1794, the authorities rounded up members of the movement and charged them with treason.<ref name="ThomasDL">{{cite book|last1=Thomas|first1=D.L|last2=Pearson|first2=Robin|title=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, England|chapter=William Morgan (1750–1833)}}</ref>

He died at [[Stamford Hill]] on 4 May 1833, and was buried at Hornsey.{{sfn|Thomas|1894}}

Other publications:
* ''The Doctrine of Annuities and Assurances on Lives and Survivorships'', 1779
* ''Computation of Premiums for Life Assurance on the Basis of the Northampton Table of Mortality'', manuscript
* ''Valuation (Individually) of the Assurance Contracts in Force in 1786'', manuscript
* ''Yearly Computation of Expected Deaths and Accounts Showing the State of the Equitable Life Assurance Society According to the Plan Suggested by Richard Price'', manuscript
* ''Nine Addresses to the General Court of the Equitable Society Covering the Years 1793 to 1830'', 1833
